We're still enrolling 3- and 4-year-olds in our free Early Childhood Education and Assistance Program (ECEAP) for 2020-21. Head to http://bit.ly/2kUgDSf to download a registration packet.

The income-qualified preschool program has sessions at Amistad Elementary School and Keewaydin Discovery Center. KSD leaders will re-evaluate the districtwide status in mid-September, given current community health data, and will continue to implement the Safe Start KSD Phased Reopening Plan (https://bit.ly/3jVHs2g). This plan shows how we'll safely transition from remote learning to hybrid learning as community health data improves.

Our staff members are working hard to prepare and deliver school meals to children at designated bus stops throughout our district.

Watch as one of our bus driver-paraeducator teams makes morning deliveries. "I love what I'm doing," paraeducator Tammy Caprai said. "I like that I'm back at work, back around people, able to see the kids and just feel like I'm contributing something."

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has extended its free meal program through December, so the meals are free at this time. They're available to all children age 18 and younger, not just Kennewick students.

Parents or guardians may pick up the meals for their kids. Please wear a face mask or face covering at the bus stop and socially distance.

The regular bus schedule has been expanded to include new stops in areas where children normally walk to school. Here's the schedule: https://bit.ly/3jfqJpl

Meet our 2020 Community Partners of the Year!

When the COVID-19 pandemic forced the closure of our school buildings this past spring, four community organizations stepped up to continue our food pantry program to help families in need.

Together, they donated, stored, hauled and handed out fresh produce and other groceries at multiple food distribution events over several weeks to families within our district who needed extra assistance.

They showed compassion, dedication, community-mindedness and heart – and we're so grateful.

We're proud to honor Second Harvest Tri-Cities, The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, Goodwill of the Columbia and the Kennewick Police Department as our 2020 Community Partners of the Year. The award is part of our annual Staff Excellence Awards program.

shared_text:
Kennewick Police Department
August 21 at 2:05 AM ·

Today, we also celebrated the retirement of an officer who, through his daily work, has had the opportunity to positively impact more lives than any other officer. Officer Mike Meyer has served our community as a patrol officer, an SRO and our longest running DARE officer at 13 years! We estimate that over Officer Meyer's DARE career he has had a positive impact on the lives of 19,000 Kennewick School District, Bethlehem Lutheran School and St. Joseph's Catholic School (Kennewick, WA) 5th graders. Officer Meyer was also instrumental in several of our other youth services programs, such as Every 15 Minutes and our crossing guard picnic. We're pretty sure there isn't a single former student who doesn't remember Officer Meyer and who doesn't remind him and say "Hi" every time they see him.

Thank you Mike for you 24 years of dedicated service to our department and our community, especially our youth.

Congratulations to Chenoa Meagher from Sage Crest Elementary on being recognized as the 2020 Washington State Regional Teacher of the Year for Educational Service District 123!

Meagher is an instructional leader who makers her kindergarten classroom a fun place to be. She’s known at Sage Crest as the “Minion Teacher” because of her room's many Minion decorations.

She's also known for her creativity – sometimes wearing costumes to liven up lessons and dreaming up characters like Even Steven and Odd Todd to help teach math concepts.

“She creates effective and engaging lessons and promotes activities that support intellectual development, while preparing students for the social challenges of kindergarten and so much more,” said Sage Crest Principal Natalie McKay.

Meagher was chosen as the 2020 Crystal Apple Award winner from the Kennewick School District and was recognized for excellence alongside educators from other school districts within ESD 123.

She’ll now be considered, along with finalists from the state's eight other ESDs, for 2021 Washington State Teacher of the Year.

-Wet your hands with clean, running water (warm or cold), turn off the tap, and apply soap.

-Lather your hands by rubbing them together with the soap. Lather the backs of your hands, between your fingers, and under your nails.

-Scrub your hands for at least 20 seconds. Need a timer? Hum the “Happy Birthday” song from beginning to end twice.

-Rinse your hands well under clean, running water.

-Dry your hands using a clean towel or air dry them.

They came for the engineering competition, and they left inspired!

High schoolers from around the Tri-Cities, including from Kennewick High School, Southridge High School and Legacy High School, took part in the annual High School Friendly Competition that brings Hanford Site engineers and teens together for a day of fun and learning.

This year, the students had to figure out an impromptu way to covert a four-inch pipe to a one-inch pipe, in the spirit of the famed Apollo 13 mission in 1970 that required on-the-fly engineering.

Debbie Meyers, a mechanical engineer and one of the event volunteers, said she hopes students were inspired to consider careers in engineering. You don't necessarily have to be at the top of the class to find success in the field, you just need an "engineering mind," she said.

"An engineering mind can be just ingenuity, working together to help solve problems. I hope that this allows the kids to see that they have some ideas they can contribute to the team and be part of it," she said.

The competition is sponsored by the Hanford Engineers Week Committee.

"It's really cool," she said. "It's a pretty great feeling."

Way to go, Nicole!

“Coming into ninth grade, I was very shy. I didn’t know much about poetry. But as part of our curriculum at Delta High School, we did the Poetry Out Loud competition. I recited this poem, ‘Revenge’ by Letitia Elizabeth Landon. For the first time, I was able to look at poetry in a new light – as more of a performance. I found myself really enjoying analyzing the poem and getting to understand why the poet wrote what she did. It was eye-opening and I just kept going with poetry. Students in Cindy Anderson's American Sign Language classes at Kennewick High School got a taste of what it's like to be deaf or hard of hearing. They spent a school day wearing earplugs and communicating only through sign, hand gestures or writing.

Anderson teaches about 116 first- and second-year students.

"You've heard that saying, 'If you could walk one mile in my shoes,' meaning if we could take somebody else's place even for a day or a short time, to try and understand what that person experiences, feels, thinks, the different obstacles that they have to deal with – it can be very valuable," she said. "That's why my students are doing this today."

A Westgate Elementary teacher recently cooked up a unique reading lesson.

Literacy specialist Susannah Luttman introduced her first- and second-graders to "Chef Blend" of the Literacy Cafe, who has a special recipe to help students learn about consonant blends, or pairs of consonants that make a blended sound, such as the “br” in the word “bread."

“The recipe is to take your ingredients (a pinch of one consonant and a dash of another) and add them together to ‘blend’ and combine them to read the sound. Then you read the word!” Mrs. Luttman said.

The students rolled out dough, used cookie cutters to make letters and got to work building words with consonant blends. The lesson was a big hit!

Watch as the Kennewick Police Department tags along on one of our bus routes as part of a special emphasis patrol to enforce stop-paddle laws.

The special patrol, which involved one officer riding on the bus and two others in an unmarked car nearby, was designed to remind the public about the importance of stopping for school buses that have their lights flashing and their stop-paddles extended to let children on or off.

"We are constantly stopping to pick up and drop off students, and we want to make sure they're as safe as possible. An emphasis patrol really brings it to light and helps the public understand that when the lights are flashing, they need to stop," said April Heiser, our transportation manager.

I never thought I'd drive a bus. Then I fell in love with it. Now I look forward to doing it."

Sandy Angotti, Kennewick School District bus driver. #iamksd

They show the old Kennewick Junior High School before and after it was damaged in a fire. Former KSD employee Harold Bell, 94, dropped by the Administration Center to share the photos and stories of the school.

He eventually retired from the school district as the printer. #tbt

Does your child have flu symptoms? Here are your flu FAQs answered...

Can my child go to school if they are sick?

No. Your child should stay home to rest and to avoid spreading flu to other children or caregivers.

When can my child go back to school after having flu?

Keep your child home from school for at least 24 hours after their fever is gone. (The fever should be gone without the use of a fever-reducing medicine.) A fever is defined as 100°F (37.8°C)* or higher.

How long can a sick person spread flu to others?

People with flu may be able to infect others from 1 day before getting sick to up to 5 to 7 days after. Severely ill people or young children may be able to spread the flu longer, especially if they still have symptoms.

Please contact your school nurse if you have more questions.

Students at Canyon View Elementary School – and in classrooms all around our school district – practiced how to "drop, cover and hold" as part of The Great ShakeOut earthquake drill. Great ShakeOut Earthquake Drills

The drill happened Thursday, Oct. 17 across Washington and worldwide.

At Canyon View, first grade teacher Nancy Evans prepared her students beforehand, explaining what to do and making sure they felt comfortable. Afterward, the class talked about the importance of "drop, cover and hold."

"Teachers were encouraged to talk with their kids and debrief about what's happened and would we may do if there was a true earthquake," said Canyon View Principal Mark Stephens. "The main focus in our school district is safety, and so that's the main focus of the great earthquake drill."

The awards also recognize high schools that have at least 90 percent of students graduate within five years of enrolling as a freshman.

Students at Lincoln Elementary School are learning a unique instrument – the ukulele! Music teacher Haviland Gilbert is teaching his fourth- and fifth-graders to play the four-stringed instrument.

"I wanted to do ukuleles because I wanted to give my students an outlet as they move forward in their lives," he said. Even if they don't go onto join band or orchestra in middle or high school, they'll still have learned a musical skill they can keep using and enjoying forever.

In his music classes, Gilbert works on active music-making, with his students trying their hands at instruments from marimba to xylophone. It's fun and engaging as well as instructive, he said.

There are several different things I love, but probably the one that stands out the most is when a student finally gets something that they’ve been working on for a really long time. The other one is the social acceptance that kids are so willing to give at a young age. We have kiddos in wheelchairs or who have different challenges – just watching them make friends, how they're accepted with kindness. There’s not a day that goes by in this job that somebody doesn’t bring you joy. That’s what it’s all about."

Kelly Dean, a special education inclusion teacher based at Keewaydin Discovery Center. #iamksd
